title: How to Make Galbi

steps.headline: Buy and butterfly the short ribs.
steps.description: Buy 3 to 4 pounds (1.3 to 1.8 kg) of English-cut beef short ribs. You can ask your butcher to butterfly the short ribs or cut them yourself. If you want to do it yourself, hold the bone and use a sharp knife to cut the meat lengthwise near the bone almost through the other end. You should be able to unfold the meat. Hold the meat near the middle and cut through the meat again, so you get a 1/4-inch (6 mm) strip that unfolds from the center. Do this for the other side of the rib. If you're having trouble butterflying the ribs, you can always cut the meat completely off of the bone in 1/4 to 1/2-inch (6 to 12 mm) strips.

steps.headline: Rinse and trim the short ribs.
steps.description: Run the short ribs under water to rinse off any blood. Drain off the excess water. Take a sharp knife and carefully cut away any fat that you can see on the short ribs. Set the short ribs aside while you make the marinade.

steps.headline: Combine the marinade.
steps.description:
Grate 1/2 of an Asian pear and 1/2 of an onion into a small prep bowl. Mince and add 2 tablespoons (17 g) of garlic and 1 teaspoon (2 g) of minced ginger. Whisk these together with the rest of the marinade ingredients until they're mixed well. You'll need to whisk in:
½ cup (120 ml) soy sauce
1 cup (240 ml) water
¼ cup (25 g) sugar
2 tablespoons (42 g) honey
¼ cup (60 ml) rice wine (or Mirin)
2 tablespoons (30 ml) sesame oil
½ teaspoon black pepper

steps.headline: Marinate the short ribs for at least 6 hours.
steps.description: Pour the marinade into a shallow baking pan and add the butterflied beef short ribs. Turn them to coat them in the marinade. Cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate the short ribs for at least 6 hours or up to overnight. If your short ribs are thick, you should marinate them longer so the marinade can penetrate the meat.

steps.headline: Prepare a grill or broiler.
steps.description: Turn a gas grill to medium heat or heat coals for a charcoal grill. Pour the coals directly onto the center of the grate to make a medium to high heat fire. If you'd rather use a broiler, just turn your broiler on to HIGH and let it heat up for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Grill or broil the short ribs for 4 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Lift the short ribs out of the marinade and lay them on the hot grill. Grill the ribs for 2 to 3 minutes and then use tongs to turn them over. Finish grilling the short ribs for 2 to 3 more minutes. If you're using a broiler, lay the meat on a broiler pan and place it about 6 inches (15 cm) below the heat source. Broil the short ribs for 5 to 6 minutes. Turn them over and cook them for 3 to 4 more minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the traditional Korean galbi.
steps.description: Serve the short ribs with steamed rice and kimchi. Or trim the meat from the bones and put pieces of the meat on lettuce and perilla leaves. Top the meat with your favorite sauce, a bit of minced garlic, and some sliced green chili peppers for heat. You can find Perilla leaves at Korean grocery stores where they're sometimes sold as sesame leaves.

steps.headline: Grate and combine the onion, Asian pear, and kiwi.
steps.description: Get out a shallow baking pan (about 7 x 11-inches or 17 x 30-cm). Set a grater into the pan and grate 1/2 of a large onion directly into the pan. Take 1/2 of a large Asian pear and remove the core. Grate the pear into the pan. You'll also need to peel 1/2 of a kiwi and grate it into the pan. Stir the mixture until it's combined.

steps.headline: Marinate the short ribs in the mixture for at least 45 minutes.
steps.description: Get out 2 1/2 pounds (1.1 kg) of LA-style beef short ribs. They should be about 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick. Lay the short ribs in the pan with the onion and fruit mixture. Cover the ribs evenly and wrap the pan with plastic wrap. Let the short ribs marinate at room temperature for 45 to 60 minutes or refrigerate them for up to 2 hours. If you can only find flanken cut, ask the butcher to slice them thinner.

steps.headline: Create the liquid marinade.
steps.description:
Combine all of the ingredients for a liquid marinade in another shallow baking pan. You'll need to stir together:
1/3 cup (80 ml) low-sodium soy sauce
2 tablespoons (30 ml) Korean soy sauce (gook-ganjang)
2 tablespoons (25 g) brown sugar
1/2 teaspoon garlic powder
1 teaspoon freshly grated ginger or 1/4 teaspoon ginger powder
1 tablespoon (15 ml) plum extract or rice wine, optional
1 tablespoon (15 ml) sesame oil
1/4 teaspoon freshly grated black pepper

steps.headline: Soak the short ribs in the liquid marinade for at least 4 hours.
steps.description: Unwrap the short ribs and use a spoon to scoop off the vegetable and fruit mixture. You can discard the mixture and place the short ribs in the liquid marinade. Turn them over so they're coated with the marinade. Cover the pan with plastic wrap and put the short ribs in the refrigerator. Chill them for at least 4 hours. If you'd like to make the LA-style galbi ahead of time, you can refrigerate it overnight.

steps.headline: Heat a grill or skillet and bring the short ribs to room temperature.
steps.description: Decide if you'd like to use a gas grill, charcoal grill, or skillet to cook the LA-style galbi. Turn on a gas grill or prepare a charcoal grill for medium heat. Or, place a large skillet on the stove and turn the heat to medium. Set the short ribs at room temperature for 15 minutes. Bringing the short ribs to room temperature will help them cook evenly.

steps.headline: Grill or saute the short ribs for 4 to 6 minutes.
steps.description: Lift the short ribs out of the marinade and lay them on the hot grill or skillet. Grill or saute the short ribs for 2 to 3 minutes. Use tongs to carefully turn them over and grill or saute them for another 2 to 3 minutes. The short ribs will cook quickly because they are cut so thinly.

steps.headline: Serve the LA-style galbi.
steps.description: You can serve the short ribs with steamed rice and kimchi. Or make them into wraps by trimming away the meat from the bones. Lay a perilla leaf on top of a piece of lettuce. Set a few bite-sized pieces of the ribs on the leaf and top the wrap with your favorite sauce, a little garlic, and some sliced green chili peppers. Perilla leaves are also sold as sesame leaves in some Korean grocery stores.
